abstract.p: Jon Pareles reviews Will You Find Me, fifth album by Ida, four-piece band (S)

block.p: IDA: ''Will You Find Me'' (Tiger Style). Voices harmonize closely, somewhere between intimacy and claustrophobia, in the quiet, unhurried songs on ''Will You Find Me,'' the fifth album by Ida. Instruments are discreet, unwilling to break a silence unnecessarily; if a lone guitar or piano is all that's needed, Ida uses nothing else.

Ida is a four-piece band intent on sounding smaller and more private, the better to contemplate questions like ''Am I still the one you wanted me to be?'' That song, ''Maybelle,'' unfolds over nearly seven minutes of billowing counterpoint, a minimalist bossa nova that never resolves itself.

Instruments are discreet, unwilling to break a silence unnecessarily; if a lone guitar or piano is all that's needed, Ida uses nothing else.

Ida is a four-piece band intent on sounding smaller and more private, the better to contemplate questions like ''Am I still the one you wanted me to be?'' That song, ''Maybelle,'' unfolds over nearly seven minutes of billowing counterpoint, a minimalist bossa nova that never resolves itself.
Even when Ida, which plays the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa on Aug. 27, allows itself to use a rock beat or guitar feedback, its songs seem hushed.
They're like the whispers of uncertain lovers in a perpetual dance of vulnerability and assurance, parting and reconciliation.
